Q1.question: An epidural catheter should be removed if: (You can select more than one answer)

options.E: Patient is not using anticoagulant / antiplatelet

Q2.question: Which of the following is the best patient position for removal of epidural catheter?

options.A: Lateral position with bilateral knee bend to chest

Q3.question: What should you do if patient complains of back pain with shooting leg pain while you are pulling out the epidural catheter?

options.C: Told patient that it is normal

Q4.question: What should you do if there is high resistance while pulling out epidural catheter?

options.A: Pull out the epidural catheter with a stronger force
options.B: Use forceps to assist pulling out the epidural catheter

Q5.question: What should you do if there is slight resistance while pulling out epidural catheter?

statements.i: Continue the procedure after reposition the patient
statements.ii: Stop the procedure immediately and inform pain team / anesthetist
statements.iii: Use forceps to assist pulling out the catheter
statements.iv: Stop the procedure if resistance is still encountered after repositioning the patient
